characterList.description: A middle-aged man with short dark hair and glasses. He wears a black long-sleeved shirt with a logo on the left breast, black pants, and yellow gloves.
characterList.name: Instructor

content_metadata.description: A video featuring swordplay instruction focusing on basic guards and cuts of the Bolognese sidesword system.

qAndA.answer: The true edge of the sword faces towards the left in the iron gate guard.
qAndA.question: What is the orientation of the true edge of the sword in the iron gate guard?

qAndA.answer: Yes, the instructor states that the tail guards can be done with either foot forward.
qAndA.question: Can the tail guards be executed with either foot forward?

qAndA.answer: The instructor mentions wrist cuts, half cuts, thrusts, and inversions of the blade, implying a total of four basic cuts.
qAndA.question: How many basic cuts are there in the system, according to the instructor?

qAndA.answer: 'Testa' means head, and the guard literally covers the head from shoulder to shoulder.
qAndA.question: What is the significance of the name 'Testa' for one of the guards?

qAndA.answer: No, the instructor explains that there is no specific long point guard, although all cuts extend through the point.
qAndA.question: Does the instructor show a specific 'long point' guard?

activities.description: The instructor welcomes viewers and introduces the topic of basic sword guards.
The instructor demonstrates two tail guards, explaining the orientation of the sword's true edge.
The instructor demonstrates two iron gates guards, highlighting the different edge orientation.
The instructor emphasizes the importance of foot positioning, specifically the toes pointing towards the opponent.
The instructor showcases the remaining guards: Alicorno (Unicorn), Testa (Window), Facha (Front), and Intraria (Another Front).
The instructor mentions the basic cuts that can be executed from the various guards.
The instructor demonstrates wrist cuts, half cuts, thrusts, and inversions of the blade.
The instructor reiterates that these basic techniques form the foundation of the system.

scenes.contextualRelevance: The focus on basic techniques underscores the importance of a strong foundation in any martial art.

narrativeProgression.description: Introduction of the eight basic guards.
Transition from discussing guards to demonstrating cuts.

scenes.thematicElements: Education, focused on imparting knowledge about Bolognese sidesword basics.
scenes.title: Basic Sword Guards Demonstration

videoEditingDetails.description: No specific transitions, effects, or music are used. The video is a single, continuous shot.
The segment on foot positioning could be shortened as the instructor repeats himself.

climax.description: Not applicable, as there is no narrative climax. The video focuses on informational presentation.

content_metadata.title: Bolognese Sidesword Guards Demonstration

trimmingSuggestions.description: The foot positioning explanation could be shortened to improve dynamism.

text_to_speech: there there's the with your toes pointed towards your shoulder to shoulder basic cuts again there are risk cuts for positions and then finally inversions of the blade all those things together and give you the fundamentals of the system King showed the guards one more time this is called the high tail if I switch sides with the blade there's two on the corner unicorn which is basically longer in prime Tesla which is finestra again it's the same way function brother Valley which is from tolling function which is from collie as well and that's

timecoded_text_to_speech.text: Continuing the series of Bolognese instructional videos, I'm going to go back to some basics.
There are roughly eight guards.
There's the tail guards, which essentially mean the true edge of the sword is facing to the right.
This was a long sword that we call Breve, and it can be done with either foot forward.
And if you switch the where the true edge is facing, these are the iron gates,
and again, it can be done with either foot forward.
And to refer back to another video, I'm going to talk about it.
Like, doing with your foot, it toes pointed towards your point.
I'm not doing this.
I'm not doing this.
I'm doing this.
My toes pointed towards my opponent.
That's four of the guards.
There's Ali Kaurma or Unicorn, or my sword is pointed directly at your opponent's face with throat.
Then there's Testa, which is finnastrace.
It goes shoulder to shoulder, that covers the head.
And it actually literally covers the head.
That's what it means, Testa.
There's also Facha, which is essentially frontali, and intraray, which is the other frontali.
And that's pretty much all the guards.
There is no specific long point, but all cuts go through there, and if you look at these guards, they're long.
The other thing I wanted to quickly look at is the basic cuts again.
There are wrist cuts, half cuts, thrusts, and we've done it in all four positions.
And then finally, inversions of the blade.
All those things together give you the fundamentals of the system.
Keep keeping sure the guards are one more time.
Sure.
So going through the guards one more time is the tight tail.
Kodolunga Stretta.
This is called the mungal to the high tail.
If I switch sides with the blade, I'll face on the other side, facing to the left.
This is the iron gate, and it's in line.
And then there's the bores tooth, which is slightly offline.
Alicorn or unicorn, which is basically longer in pride.
Testa, which is finnastra.
Again, it's done the same way.
Facha, or rather in drali, which is frantali.
Facha, which is in frantali as well.
And that's the basics of the system.

youtube_channel: Academy of European Medieval Martial Arts
youtube_description:
Welcome to the Academy of European Medieval Martial Arts Youtube Archive!

New and Prospective Students join our FB page!

Our Contact Info and Social Media:

-------------------------------

Our Facebook Page:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/AEMMA.1998

Our Facebook page is our principle news source; join us there and watch that page for all updates and news!!

-------------------------------

Our Youtube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/AEMMAchannel

Our Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/aemma_toronto/

Our Website: www.aemma.org

AEMMA's Archery Program: https://www.facebook.com/aemmaarchery

-------------------------------

Join this page and subscribe to our youtube channel to watch out for updates, events, photos, and videos!

New Students: 

AEMMA Toronto admits new students through our Introductory Course (other AEMMA Chapters have different introductions, please email them for info). The Introductory Course is held every second month of the year (or less) for a total of one month, beginning in January. Once you complete the course, you will be ready to join the main AEMMA recruit class. 

If you have any further questions, please email AEMMA Toronto at toronto@aemma.org

See you there!

For more information about AEMMA, from general inquiries to curriculum to pricing, please send an email to:
AEMMA Toronto: toronto@aemma.org
AEMMA Guelph: guelph@aemma.org
AEMMA Stratford: stratford@aemma.org
AEMMA Digby: digby@aemma.org
AEMMA Ottawa: ottawa@aemma.org

The Academy of European Medieval Martial Arts or AEMMA (pronounced "ehma"), is a historical European martial arts school focused on the research, reconstruction and resurrection of authentic medieval martial arts of all fighting styles (armed, unarmed, armoured and unarmoured), firmly based on the works of the late 14th century Friulian swordmaster by the name of Fiore dei Liberi, demonstrating the deadly practicality and effectiveness of the art as it applies to today's personal self-defense.

AEMMA was initially created in May of 1998 in  Toronto, Canada and under the laws of Ontario's Corporations Act and the Regulations of the Ministry of the Attorney General, was incorporated as a not-for-profit corporation (NPO Corporation Number: 1468524) in May 28, 2001. It has as its mission:

"The mission of AEMMA is to resurrect the combat skills, philosophies and principles of an accomplished European Medieval martial artist and to achieve a state which would be consistent with that of a medieval warrior in both technology and ideal."  

Apart from its founding Toronto chapter, AEMMA also has 4 vibrant chapters in Guelph, Stratford, and Ottawa Ontario, and Digby Nova Scotia.
